```{r}
#Define a list MA_days. The author used three different moving average periods of 10, 20 and 30. These are the commonly used moving average days.
MA_days <- c(10, 20, 30)
#Since there are insufficient windows, so I fill in NA value.

for(i in 1:20){
  temp = eval(parse(text =company_list[i]))
  temp$`MA10` <- rollmean(temp$Adjusted, k = 10, fill = NA,align = "right")
  temp$`MA20` <- rollmean(temp$Adjusted, k = 20, fill = NA,align = "right")
  temp$`MA30` <- rollmean(temp$Adjusted, k = 30, fill = NA,align = "right")
  assign(company_list[i],temp)
}
rm(temp)

for(i in 1:20){
  print(head(eval(parse(text =company_list[i])), 5))
}
```
```{r}
#Define a function plot_graphic to draw charts, and draw the smoothed data of 20 companies (columns 6 to 9)
plot_graphic <- function(company, company_string) {
  matplot(company[, 6:9], type = "l", xlab = "Date", ylab = "Price", main = company_string, col = 1:4)
  legend("topleft", legend = colnames(company)[6:9], col = 1:4, lty = 1, cex = 0.8)
}

for (company_name in company_list) {   
  company_data <- eval(parse(text = company_name))
  plot_graphic(company_data, company_name)
}
```
```{r}
#Calculate the difference of the Adjusted column
#Use the lines function to add Kernel Density Estimation to an existing graph
calculate_daily_returns <- function(company_data) {
  company_data$`Daily Returns` <- diff(company_data$Adjusted) / lag(company_data$Adjusted, 1)
  return(company_data)
}

plot_daily_returns_histogram <- function(company_data, company_name) {
  daily_returns <- na.omit(company_data$`Daily Returns`)
  hist(daily_returns, breaks = 50, col = 'dodgerblue', main = company_name, xlab = 'Daily Returns', ylab = 'Count', ylim = c(0, 40))
  lines(density(daily_returns), col = "blue", lwd = 2)
}

for (company_name in company_list) {
  company_data <- eval(parse(text = company_name))
  company_data <- calculate_daily_returns(company_data)
  assign(company_name, company_data)
  plot_daily_returns_histogram(company_data, company_name)
}
```
